PostValue.explanation: This post compiles strong, widely corroborated survey evidence that the public — including many smokers and many doctors — misunderstand the nicotine/tobacco continuum of risk. For the EA community it’s fairly high‑value (7) because, if correct, it points to a tractable, neglected intervention area (targeted information campaigns, funding consumer advocacy, and rigorous evaluation) that could cheaply reduce very large burdens of disease from smoking. It isn’t foundational to EA/worldview decisions (there remain important behavioral, policy, and second‑order uncertainties), but it is load‑bearing for prioritizing a plausible global‑health cause area. For general humanity it’s moderately important (6): the potential impact is large (smoking causes massive mortality), but whether correcting misperceptions would reliably change behavior at scale, and the political/industry constraints, remain uncertain — so the claim is consequential but not determinative without further rigorous evaluation.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Weak treatment of potential bias / conflict of interest. You disclose a pro-harm-reduction bias and funding ties only in the epigraph, but the post reads advocacy-forward and doesn’t show steps you took to avoid or test for bias. Actionable fixes: add a short, explicit methodology paragraph saying how you selected studies (search terms, inclusion/exclusion criteria), flag where industry-funded research appears in your citations, and (if possible) ask an independent reviewer with no THR ties to read a draft and confirm that your interpretation of key studies is balanced. If you can’t get that, at minimum soften the language in the conclusions to reflect uncertainty from potential author bias.

2) Over-reliance on survey numbers without critical appraisal of survey quality and causality. You treat many survey percentages as strong evidence that misinformation causes poor health outcomes, but you don’t discuss key limitations like question wording, sampling frames, response bias, cultural/timing differences, or whether changing beliefs actually changes behavior. Actionable fixes: add a short methods appendix or a one-paragraph caveat that summarizes (a) variation in survey questions and representativeness for the main studies you cite, (b) the absence of strong causal evidence that correcting perceptions -> switching -> health gains, and (c) recommend what kinds of studies are most informative (pre-registered experiments, RCTs of information interventions with behavioral endpoints, or meta-analyses). If possible, cite at least one systematic review or high-quality longitudinal study that speaks to belief–behavior links (or explicitly state that such evidence is sparse).

3) Insufficient engagement with the strongest counterarguments (population-level harms, youth initiation, precautionary rationale of WHO/NGOs). You call some NGO and WHO statements “false” but don’t acknowledge the legitimate reasons those organizations have been cautious (precautionary principle, uncertainties about youth uptake/renormalization, population-wide modeling). That makes the critique read as selective. Actionable fixes: (a) add a short section summarizing the most plausible population-level counterarguments (gateway/renormalization, youth initiation, net effects in different regulatory contexts), (b) explain why you think those concerns are outweighed/insufficient or state where uncertainty remains, and (c) include or point to population-level models and empirical evidence that support your position or explain what further modeling would be needed. This will make the post more persuasive to skeptical readers and reduce the risk of an own goal.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback targets three central weaknesses that could plausibly embarrass the author if raised publicly: weak methods/bias handling given disclosed industry ties, treating heterogeneous survey results as strong causal evidence, and failing to fairly engage with population-level counterarguments (e.g. WHO’s precautionary rationale). Each point is actionable and would materially increase credibility without requiring a huge rewrite. It isn’t a perfect 10 because these fixes don’t overturn the core empirical claims, but they are critical for persuasion and avoiding obvious "own goals."

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I find no evidence up to June 2024 that 'Kristof Redei' is a known figure in the EA/rationalist community (no notable posts on LessWrong/EA forum, talks, or affiliation with major EA orgs) or in broader public/professional circles. The name may be a pseudonym or confused with other similarly spelled Hungarian mathematicians (e.g., Rédei), but there are no clear publications, media coverage, or citation records tying this exact name to prominence. If you can provide links or context, I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: Overall very clear and well structured. The post has a concise summary and useful epistemic note, logical headings, and abundant citations that make the argument easy to follow: many people (including users and doctors) misperceive the nicotine/tobacco risk continuum, and correcting this could be a high‑impact intervention. Strengths: clear thesis, good organization (summary, who, why, what’s been done, what could be done), concrete survey evidence and sources. Weaknesses: fairly long and occasionally dense (some sections list many studies in rapid succession), a few places use loaded language or assume prior knowledge of THR debates, and the recommendations could be tightened and more explicitly linked to the cited effect sizes. Streamlining lists of studies and tightening the recommendations would improve conciseness and persuasive force.

PostNovelty.explanation: For an EA Forum audience the core claims are mostly familiar: tobacco harm reduction, the 'continuum of risk', and that public/doctor misperceptions are widespread have been discussed repeatedly in specialized circles. The post's contribution is largely a useful synthesis and compilation of survey evidence (e.g. the large physician poll, cross-country trends) and an EA-flavored push for evaluating information campaigns — valuable but not conceptually new. For the general educated public the specific scale and pervasiveness of misperceptions (including among doctors and major NGOs) and the international survey examples may be somewhat surprising, but the underlying ideas are not highly original.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post is logically organized, cites a wide range of studies, draws plausible connections (misinformation → worse decisions), and explicitly notes limits and alternative explanations. It transparently gives its epistemic status and outlines testable interventions (e.g. evaluations). Weaknesses: Much of the empirical support comes from cross-sectional surveys with heterogeneous methods and populations (so representativeness, measurement, and temporal issues matter), some citations are to non‑academic or advocacy sources, and causal claims (that correcting beliefs would be highly cost‑effective) are asserted with limited direct causal or behavioral evidence (few RCTs or large evals). Author bias and some contested characterizations (e.g. of WHO/NGO messaging) further weaken definitive conclusions. Overall, the core claim—that many users and many clinicians hold inaccurate beliefs—is well supported; claims about impact and cost‑effectiveness of remediation are more tentative and need stronger causal evidence.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most major empirical claims in the post are well-supported by peer‑reviewed surveys and official reports: national and multi‑country surveys show large, persistent misperceptions about nicotine and the relative harms of vaping/other non‑combustible products among the general public, people who smoke, and many clinicians; trends also show worsening perceptions since mid‑2010s (notably after EVALI). Key supporting evidence includes JAMA and AJPM national analyses, large multi‑country surveys, physician surveys (Rutgers; Global Action to End Smoking), CDC investigations of EVALI, and national guidance (NHS, NZ). Weaknesses/nuance: a few of the author’s characterizations (e.g., calling specific WHO language “false statements”) are interpretive rather than purely empirical (though WHO messaging is demonstrably more cautionary than harm‑reduction oriented and has been publicly criticized); some small date/wording imprecisions appear in the post but do not change the substantive pattern of evidence. Overall: strong, convergent evidence supports the core claim that many relevant populations are misinformed about the continuum of risk, so the post is largely accurate and well referenced.

JAMA Network Open (UCL) — Trends in Harm Perceptions of E‑Cigarettes vs Cigarettes Among Adults Who Smoke in England, 2014–2023 (28,393 respondents; decline from ~44% in 2014 to ~27% thinking vaping is less harmful by 2023). ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10902732/?utm_source=openai))

Global Action to End Smoking — Doctors’ Survey (Sermo) 2022 (15,335 physicians across 11 countries; large percentages of physicians endorsed the belief that nicotine directly causes cancers/COPD etc.). ([globalactiontoendsmoking.org](https://globalactiontoendsmoking.org/research/global-polls-and-surveys/doctors-survey/?utm_source=openai))

Rutgers / Journal of General Internal Medicine & MDPI studies — physician surveys (e.g., Rutgers-led national survey and randomized survey experiment showing persistent misperceptions among US physicians about nicotine causing cancer, CVD, COPD). ([rutgers.edu](https://www.rutgers.edu/news/rutgers-led-national-survey-uncovers-doctors-misconceptions-about-nicotine-risks?utm_source=openai), [pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8306881/?utm_source=openai))

MDPI IJERPH — Perception of Harmfulness of Various Tobacco Products and E‑Cigarettes in Poland (2021) (national survey: <25% thought e‑cigs/HTPs were less harmful than cigarettes). ([mdpi.com](https://www.mdpi.com/1660-4601/18/16/8793))

Emerald / multi‑country survey — Perceptions of nicotine in current and former users across seven countries (large proportions incorrectly view nicotine as the primary cause of smoking‑related cancer). ([emerald.com](https://www.emerald.com/insight/content/doi/10.1108/DAT-04-2020-0022/full/html?utm_source=openai))

CDC MMWR and related reports on EVALI (2019–2020) — vitamin E acetate in illicit THC products implicated in outbreak; CDC commentary on how the outbreak affected public perceptions. ([cdc.gov](https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6903e2.htm?utm_source=openai))

NHS (UK) — 'Vaping to quit smoking' guidance (explicitly states vaping is less harmful than smoking and provides practical guidance). ([nhs.uk](https://www.nhs.uk/better-health/quit-smoking/ready-to-quit-smoking/vaping-to-quit-smoking/?utm_source=openai))

WHO — e‑cigarette factsheets / Q&A and related WHO statements (cautionary framing emphasizing that e‑cigs are harmful and long‑term effects uncertain); and contemporaneous critiques by UK researchers reported in Science. ([who.int](https://www.who.int/news-room/questions-and-answers/item/tobacco-e-cigarettes?utm_source=openai), [science.org](https://www.science.org/content/article/who-warning-vaping-draws-harsh-response-uk-researchers?utm_source=openai))
